message_1: A sample of radioactive material has a half-life of 10 years. If the initial mass of the material was 400 grams, how much will be left after 20 years?
message_2:
To determine the amount of radioactive material remaining after a certain number of years, we can use the formula:

Final mass = Initial mass * (1/2)^(number of years / half-life)

In this case, the initial mass is 400 grams, the half-life is 10 years, and we want to find the remaining mass after 20 years.

Final mass = 400 * (1/2)^(20 / 10)

Final mass = 400 * (1/2)^2

Final mass = 400 * (1/4)

Final mass = 100 grams

After 20 years, there will be 100 grams of the radioactive material left.
